Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Ask questions that arise from careful observation of phenomena, models, or unexpected results, to clarify and/or seek additional information.
Rationale: Students’ questions for the Driving Question Board (DQB) emerge from their observations of the temperature changes in the regular/fancy cups and their experiences with related phenomena or other objects that keep things cold and hot. Students’ questions are developed to seek clarity in their systems models to explain what is happening when the cups and related objects are more or less successful at maintaining a substance’s temperature.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Ask questions that can be investigated within the scope of the classroom, outdoor environment, and museums and other public facilities with available resources and, when appropriate, frame a hypothesis based on observations and scientific principles.
Rationale: When students generate a list of questions for the DQB, they are encouraged to generate investigable questions that they can pursue in the classroom given available resources. These questions will form the background of the investigations conducted over the course of the unit.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to predict and/or describe phenomena.
Rationale: Students develop initial systems models to describe how the fancy cup maintains a drink’s temperature better than the regular cup.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms.
Rationale: Students are encouraged to include in their model unobservable mechanisms, like heat, cold, gases, and so forth, that could be entering or leaving their cup systems.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design: identify independent and dependent variables and controls, what tools are needed to do the gathering, how measurements will be recorded, and how many data are needed to support a claim.
Rationale: In groups, students plan an investigation into how changing 1 cup feature affects a drink’s temperature over time, and they explore the importance of keeping all other variables constant (e.g., initial water temperature, amount of water and ice, methods for reading and recording temperature, and timed measurement intervals). As part of their plan, students describe their experimental setup, materials required, and data collection methodology.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data about the performance of a proposed object, tool, process or system under a range of conditions
Rationale: Students collect data to analyze the performance of a series of cups under a range of conditions (e.g., lid or no lid, single or double walls, and cup material).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Use graphical displays (e.g., maps, charts, graphs, and/or tables) of large data sets to identify temporal and spatial relationships.
Rationale: Using a class data table, students analyze the data to identify patterns in the effect of various cup features on temperature change over time (i.e., temporal patterns in the data).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena.
Rationale: Using class data, students identify patterns indicating that some cup features seem to work better at keeping a drink cold.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Consider limitations of data analysis (e.g., 
measurement error), and/or seek to improve precision and accuracy of data with better 
technological tools and methods (e.g., multiple trials).
Rationale: Through data analysis, students identify outliers and data that seem counterintuitive. They suggest ways to modify data collection methods in subsequent investigations to improve the precision and accuracy of data.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Analyze and interpret data to determine similarities and differences in findings.
Rationale: Using class data, students highlight similarities and differences to identify patterns indicating which cup features seem most essential for keeping a drink cold.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to predict and/or describe phenomena.
Rationale: Students develop a model to explain how cup features not only slow the warming up of a cold liquid inside the cup but can also work to slow the cooling down of a hot liquid inside the cup.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms.
Rationale: Students use their model to identify the non-visible components, relationships, and processes that lead to temperature changes in a liquid and how cup features can slow this process.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design: identify independent and dependent variables and controls, what tools are needed to do the gathering, how measurements will be recorded, and how many data are needed to support a claim.
Rationale: Students work in teams focused on how to test the lid’s role in maintaining the temperature of the liquid inside the cup. Students identify one independent variable to change, identify controlled variables, and determine how they will measure the outcomes. Students do not use independent, dependent, or controlled variables in their language yet, but will be primed for learning those new words in the subsequent lesson.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to predict and/or describe phenomena.
Rationale: Students develop and use a model to predict whether, and explain why, the hot liquid in the cup with a lid or without a lid will drop in temperature more in their first investigation. They also develop and use a particulate model of matter to show that more matter is leaving the system with no lid than the system with a lid.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms.
Rationale: Students develop and use a model to describe unobservable mechanisms (evaporation and escape of gases through gaps between the lid and the cup) that could account for matter entering or leaving their cup systems.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Evaluate the accuracy of various methods for collecting data.
Rationale: Students plan and design their first investigation collaboratively, identifying independent, dependent, and control variables, what tools are needed for data gathering, and how measurements will be recorded.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data about the performance of a proposed object, tool, process or system under a range of conditions
Rationale:
Students take measurements to produce 
data (temperature changes and mass changes) to serve as the basis for evidence to answer scientific questions (“How does a lid affect what happens to the liquid in the cup?”) in their two investigations.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena.
Rationale: Students analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena when they make claims about the effect of a lid versus no lid on temperature changes and mass changes in each investigation.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Apply concepts of statistics and probability (including mean, median, mode, and variability) to analyze and characterize data, using digital tools when feasible.
Rationale: Students apply concepts of statistics and probability when they calculate the mean to analyze and characterize the average temperature change and mass change for different portions of their pooled class data.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Consider limitations of data analysis (e.g., 
measurement error), and/or seek to improve precision and accuracy of data with better 
technological tools and methods (e.g., multiple trials).
Rationale:
Students consider limitations of data analysis when the teacher explains the accuracy of the digital scale (+/- 0.1 g) and how averaging multiple 
measurements from many trials can help 
counterbalance this source of error.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Analyze and interpret data to determine similarities and differences in findings.
Rationale: Students analyze and interpret data to determine similarities and differences in findings when they compare temperature and mass changes in their investigations and look for patterns across the pooled class data sets.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena.
Rationale: Students collect and interpret mass measurements and observational data in the classroom, compare these to related personal experiences, and then use this evidence to explain that condensation occurs when moisture in the air collects on a cool surface.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Construct, use, and/or present an oral and written argument supported by empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support or refute an 
explanation or a model for a phenomenon or a solution to a problem.
Rationale: Students develop an argument, using evidence from the investigation and personal experiences of condensation, to argue that water forming on the outside of the cup comes from the air as opposed to coming from inside the cup.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop or modify a model—based on evidence—to match what happens if a variable or component of a system is changed.
Rationale: Students develop and modify a model—based on evidence--to match what happens if a variable or component of a system is changed. They do this when they account for the results from an open system (a cup with no lid) and a less-open system (a cup with a lid) when they work with marble manipulatives on day 1, diagrammatic models at the end of day 1, and Questions 3 and 4 on the assessment on day 2.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Develop and/or revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable but predict observable 
phenomena.
Rationale:
Students develop and revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable (particle flow out of the system 
versus no particle flow out of the system) but that predict observable phenomena to explain the effect of a lid versus no lid on mass loss (or no mass loss) from the system. They do this when they work with marble manipulatives on day 1, diagrammatic models at the end of day 1, and Questions 3 and 4 on the assessment on day 2.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to predict and/or describe phenomena.
Rationale:
Students develop and use a model to predict and describe phenomena to answer Questions A through E on [material: TH.L6.HO2] and Questions 3 and 4 on the 
assessment.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms.
Rationale: Students develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms when they model evaporation and matter loss from a cup system through gaps between the lid and the cup wall to explain why a lidded cup could still lose mass when they complete the questions for B through E and the zoom-in models for E on [material: TH.L6.HO2].

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design: identify independent and dependent variables and controls, what tools are needed to do the gathering, how measurements will be recorded, and how many data are needed to support a claim.
Rationale:
Students plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design they identify: the independent, dependent, and control variables, what tools are needed to gather the data, how 
measurements will be recorded, and how much data are needed to support a claim when they answer Question 2 on [material: TH.L6.SA] on day 2.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Develop and/or revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable but predict observable 
phenomena.
Rationale:
Since students have figured out that matter does not enter or leave the closed cup system, they 
determine other possible causes for a temperature change in a liquid in the system. Students develop a model that predicts the interactions between energy and the components of the closed cup system to explain what could cause the liquid’s temperature change.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop or modify a model—based on evidence—to match what happens if a variable or component of a system is changed.
Rationale: Students modify a model from Lesson 7—based on evidence from the light experiment in this lesson--to account for what happens to the temperature of water inside a cup if there is no light shining on the cup (a variable or component of a system is changed).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Develop and/or revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable but predict observable 
phenomena.
Rationale:
Students apply their model from the unit on light and matte to explain how relationships between observed amounts of reflected, transmitted, and 
absorbed light lead to temperature changes inside cups with various surfaces.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design: identify independent and dependent variables and controls, what tools are needed to do the gathering, how measurements will be recorded, and how many data are needed to support a claim.
Rationale:
Students work as a class (or in small groups) to add to and review an investigation plan to test 
temperature changes using a cup system inserted into a water bath system. Students will write a testable question, discuss the independent, dependent, and control variables, and decide how to collect temperature data to get accurate results.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop a model to describe unobservable mechanisms.
Rationale: Students have multiple opportunities to develop a model to explain how matter is made of particles, how the particles move in relation to one another, and how the movement of particles relates to the temperature of the matter.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to generate data to test ideas about phenomena in natural or designed systems, including those representing inputs and outputs, and those at unobservable scales.
Rationale: During the Food Coloring Lab, students apply their observations of hot and cold water to develop a model that predicts particle behavior in room temperature water.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Apply scientific ideas, principles, and/or evidence to construct, revise and/or use an explanation for real world phenomena, examples, or events.
Rationale: Students apply scientific ideas about how particles in hot liquids move faster and have more kinetic energy than particles in cold liquids to construct an explanation about their observations of food coloring moving more in hot water than in cold water. They extend these ideas to gases as well.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence to answer scientific questions or test design solutions under a range of conditions.
Rationale:
Because it is not possible to directly observe matter at the particle level, students use an online interactive simulation to observe the motion of the particles in a gas as well as the interactions 
(collisions) between the particles which result in transfers of kinetic energy between the particles. Students use the simulation to generate and collect data to figure out the relationship between the kinetic energy of the particles in a gas, the 
temperature of the gas, and its total kinetic energy.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Apply concepts of statistics and probability (including mean, median, mode, and variability) to analyze and characterize data, using digital tools when feasible.
Rationale:
Students engage with the simulation by first selecting the number of particles and the 
temperature of the sample of matter (gas). This allows them to observe the interactions (collisions) between the particles. They have opportunities to adjust the temperature and/or number of particles and collect and analyze data, including the speed of the fastest and slowest particles, changes in the total kinetic energy of the particles, and the temperature of the gas.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Use mathematical representations to describe and/or support scientific conclusions and design solutions.
Rationale: Students use mathematical representations and computational thinking as they gather, analyze, and compare data, including average kinetic energy of the particles of a gas (temperature), total kinetic energy of the particles, and the range of speed between the slowest and fastest particles.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to generate data to test ideas about phenomena in natural or designed systems, including those representing inputs and outputs, and those at unobservable scales.
Rationale: Students use a model to generate data to test ideas about phenomena in natural or designed systems, including those representing inputs and outputs and those at unobservable scales both in their work with marbles and computer simulations, acoss activities #1-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence to answer scientific questions or test design solutions under a range of conditions.
Rationale: Students collect data to serve as the basis for evidence to answer scientific questions or to test under a range of conditions in their work with marbles and computer simulations, acoss activities #1-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Construct, use, and/or present an oral and written argument supported by empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support or refute an 
explanation or a model for a phenomenon or a solution to a problem.
Rationale: Students organize and use evidence to support claims that temperature changes are due to the movement of heat rather than cold between samples of matter.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to generate data to test ideas about phenomena in natural or designed systems, including those representing inputs and outputs, and those at unobservable scales.
Rationale: Students co-develop a model as a class that they will then use in their groups to design features for their cups that will minimize energy transfer. They will use their model to justify their design choices and to guide them as they test and redesign their cups.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Critically read scientific texts adapted for classroom use to determine the central ideas and/or obtain scientific and/or technical information to describe patterns in and/or evidence about the natural and designed world(s).
Rationale: Students read about a design feature widely used in cups to keep beverages cold or warm. They determine important ideas from the reading that help them make connections to previous ideas they have already developed. They use this information to gain both scientific and technical information that will help them design their own cups in the design challenge.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Communicate scientific and/or technical information (e.g. about a proposed object, tool, process, system) in writing and/or
Rationale: Students develop posters that include big ideas and a model to communicate scientific information about a certain design feature used in cups and how it slows energy transfer.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data about the performance of a proposed object, tool, process or system under a range of conditions
Rationale: Students collect data about the performance of their cup systems under specified testing situations so that tests across all the cups are fairly done.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Undertake a design project, engaging in the design cycle, to construct and/or implement a solution that meets specific design criteria and constraints.
Rationale: Students work in groups to undertake a design challenge for a cup to minimize energy transfer, engaging in one design cycle to meet specific design criteria and constraints.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Collect data about the performance of a proposed object, tool, process or system under a range of conditions
Rationale: Students collect an additional round of data about the performance of their redesigned cup systems under specified testing situations so that tests across all the cups are fairly done. This allows students to make comparisons between their first cup design and their new cup design.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Undertake a design project, engaging in the design cycle, to construct and/or implement a solution that meets specific design criteria and constraints.
Rationale: Students work in groups to complete a second design cycle to better meet specific design criteria and constraints. They focus on redesigning their cups to either improve performance on the criteria or to better meet the constraints, or both.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Optimize performance of a design by prioritizing criteria, making tradeoffs, testing, revising, and re testing.
Rationale:
Students redesign their cups to optimize 
performance of the cups. Prior to beginning the second design cycle, students reflect on the design process. Part of this reflection may include 
prioritizing criteria, making tradeoffs, and evaluating the testing process. The reflection will vary from class to class depending on how the first design cycle in Lesson 16 went.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Develop and/or revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable but predict observable 
phenomena.
Rationale: Students develop a generalized model for energy transfer that accounts for unobservable mechanisms for energy transfer via radiation and conduction from air, and that can be used to predict observable phenomena.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Develop and/or use a model to predict and/or describe phenomena.
Rationale: Students will develop a more generalized model for energy transfer that includes both conduction and radiation combined, and then use the model to make predictions about how the model would change with certain devices in which some of the variables in the system are different (e.g., white cooler versus dark blue cooler).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Apply scientific ideas or principles to design, construct, and/or test a design of an object, tool, process or system.
Rationale: Students will apply scientific ideas and principles to evaluate the designs for proposed disaster relief blankets. They will need to apply ideas about energy transfer via conduction or radiation to make sense of the test results for each design option.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Science and Engineering Practice(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: Students set up a model of the cup system and are prompted to think about the important parts of the system, what could be entering the system (inputs) or leaving it (outputs), and the processes that cause the drink to warm up or stay the same temperature.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.
Rationale:
Students examine the structural components of the regular cup and fancy cup to identify similarities and differences that may be related to how well the cups performed at maintaining the drink’s temperature. 
They compare these structural components to those observed in related systems that are designed to keep things hot or cold.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Patterns can be used to identify cause and effect relationships.
Rationale: By examining patterns in the class data, students identify which cup features play a more significant role in keeping a drink cold.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Crosscutting Concept(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Graphs, charts, and images can be used to identify patterns in data.
Rationale: By analyzing class data, students identify patterns indicating the role that specific cup features play in keeping a drink cold.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: Students revise their cup system model to explain which features work best for keeping things (e.g., air, heat, energy, cold, light) from entering the system (inputs) or leaving it (outputs), thus allowing the drink to stay cold longer.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale:
Students construct cup system models to explain how features of the best-performing and worst performing cup systems work to affect the 
temperature change of liquids inside the cup systems.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.
Rationale: Students plan an investigation to test one structural feature of the cup system: the lid. Students generate ideas about why the lid may be important to the system and work in small groups to plan how to investigate how the lid works to maintain the temperature of the liquid inside or to slow the warming up or cooling down process.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Macroscopic patterns are related to the nature of microscopic and atomic-level structure.
Rationale: Students account for macroscopic patterns based on the nature of changes at the microscopic level (particulate model of matter) when they use the chip manipulatives to explain what is happening to the liquid water in the system (evaporation) over time. They use this idea again when they annotate and explain what the class consensus models show with regard to how the particles in the solid cup walls, the liquid (the water), and gases (the air) interact in a open system vs. a less open system.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: Students use the idea that models can represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes, and outputs—related to matter flow into, out of, and within the system when they develop and use models of the different systems and zoom in circles for different subsystem boundaries to visualize what is happening to particles of the matter at those boundaries at the end of days 2 and 3.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Matter is conserved because atoms are conserved in physical and chemical processes.
Rationale: Students use the idea that matter is conserved because atoms are conserved in physical processes when they explain why the mass of the mostly closed (lidded) system remained mostly the same while the mass of the more open (unlidded) system decreased.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Patterns can be used to identify cause and effect relationships.
Rationale: Students observe changes to the outside of a cup of cold water and measure changes in mass before and after droplets of water form on the outside of the cup to determine whether these droplets formed due to water that came from inside the cup system. They compare their lab data to other experiences of condensation to establish patterns for the conditions necessary for condensation to occur.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Matter is conserved because atoms are conserved in physical and chemical processes.
Rationale: Students use changes in mass to argue that the matter inside the cup does not leave through the cup walls. The water droplets that form on the outside of the cup system are made up of matter from the air on the outside of the cup system.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Crosscutting Concept(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Macroscopic patterns are related to the nature of microscopic and atomic-level structure.
Rationale: Students account for macroscopic patterns based on the nature of changes at the microscopic level (particulate model of matter) when they use marble manipulatives and drawn diagrams to explain what is happening to the liquid water and water vapor in the system when it reaches a solid boundary (e.g., cup wall or lid) on day 1 of the lesson.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: Students use cause-and-effect relationships to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems when they answer Questions 3 and 4 on [material: TH.L6.SA] to connect structural differences (different-sized openings in the lid) to describe and predict which cup would lose mass faster and decrease in temperature faster.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Phenomena may have more than one cause, and some cause and effect relationships in systems can only be described using probability.
Rationale: Students understand that phenomena may have more than one cause when they consider Question 5 in [material: TH.L6.ASMT], which problematizes how an airtight system can still undergo a temperature change even if it is exchanging no matter with the outside (which was one cause students have already identified as contributing to temperature changes).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: Students use the idea that models can represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes, and outputs—related to matter inside and outside the system when they develop and use models of two different cups, using zoom-in circles at different subsystem boundaries to visualize what is happening to particles of the matter in the liquid, solid, and gas there. They do this in the small-group activity on day 1 and in the independent assessment at the end of day 2.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Matter is conserved because atoms are conserved in physical and chemical processes.
Rationale:
Students use the idea that matter is conserved in physical processes and start to develop the idea that some other form of flow (e.g., energy) must be entering or exiting the system to explain how an airtight container (closed system) with cold or hot liquid can warm up or cool down to room 
temperature without any mass loss in the navigation discussion at the end of day 2.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Complex and microscopic structures and systems can be visualized, modeled, and used to describe how their function depends on the shapes, 
composition, and relationships among its parts; therefore, complex natural and designed 
structures/systems can be analyzed to determine how they function.
Rationale: Students model microscopic structures and systems and visualize how their function depends on the shapes and relationships among the parts, with regard to the amount of space between neighboring particles in a solid versus gaps between the cup’s lid and wall, to explain why water molecules can escape through some points in the cup system but not others. They do this when they complete the zoom in models for Questions D and E on [material: TH.L6.HO2].

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac:
Complex and microscopic structures and systems can be visualized, modeled, and used to describe how their function depends on the shapes, 
composition, and relationships among its parts; therefore, complex natural and designed 
structures/systems can be analyzed to determine how they function.
Rationale: Students think about and analyze what they understand about the components and structures of the closed cup system, how the components and structures function, and how they interact with one another and with other objects and substances that are not part of the cup system. Students use what they know to determine what else might be interacting with the system to cause a temperature change in the liquid inside, and they problematize how to test these ideas to figure out how these interactions occur at the particle level.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Crosscutting Concept(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: Students identify the key relationships between amounts of light and temperature changes. Students consider the underlying mechanisms that can explain how these relationships give rise to the observed temperature changes.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: The Water Bath Lab is a model to represent how energy moves between systems. Students will focus on recording temperature changes inside and outside the cup system but will not connect temperature measurements to the kinetic energy of particles until Lessons 10 and 11.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Phenomena that can be observed at one scale may not be observable at another scale.
Rationale: By adding food coloring to water of varying temperatures, students can better visualize the movement in water at the particle scale.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Phenomena that can be observed at one scale may not be observable at another scale.
Rationale: Students consider what happened in the Food Coloring Lab and realize that we cannot observe particles’ motion with our naked eye, only the collective behavior of particles and how that affects things like the spread of food coloring and dyes. Students watch a simulation at the particle scale and observe that particles are moving fast in hot water and slowly in cold water.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Patterns can be used to identify cause and effect relationships.
Rationale: The online simulation uses different shades of color and/or varying lengths of trails to indicate the speed (amount of kinetic energy) of individual particles of a gas. As students observe particle motion in the simulation, they look for recurring patterns in the changes that occur as the particles collide. These collisions result in transfers of energy between particles, which manifest as changes in color and/or trail length. Students use this information to determine a cause-and-effect relationship between particle speed and the energy transfers that occur when particles collide.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: As students observe recurring patterns of change in particle speed due to collisions, they determine a cause-and-effect relationship between the kinetic energy of individual particles and the transfer of energy that occurs when particles collide. Students use this relationship to make predictions about changes in the temperature of particles in other types of matter as they interact.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Grades 3-5: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions.
Rationale: Students use the simulation to observe matter at the particle level, which is at a scale too small to observe with the tools available in middle school science classrooms. The simulation allows students to observe the motion of and interactions between the particles in a gas to determine how particle collisions result in transfers of energy.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Macroscopic patterns are related to the nature of microscopic and atomic-level structure.
Rationale: Students account for macroscopic patterns based on the nature of changes at the microscopic level (particulate model of matter) when they use simulations and marble manipulatives to explore how collisions between particles in a sample of matter account for speed changes in the particles, and for subsequent changes in the temperature of the matter, in activities #1-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Crosscutting Concept(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: Students use cause-and-effect relationships to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems when they (1) explore how particle collisions between fast-moving particles (marbles) in solids, liquids, and gases can transfer kinetic energy to other particles they collide with in activities #1-4 and (2) consider how the size of a solid, its temperature, and the amount of the solid in contact with surrounding material affect the amount of thermal energy transfer (total kinetic energy at a particle level) to and from surrounding matter in activities #5-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Phenomena may have more than one cause, and some cause and effect relationships in systems can only be described using probability.
Rationale: Students understand that phenomena may have more than one cause when they consider how the size of a solid, its temperature, and the amount of the solid in contact with surrounding material affect the amount of thermal energy transfer (total kinetic energy at a particle level) to and from surrounding matter in activities #5-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes andoutputs— and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.
Rationale: Students use the idea that models can represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes, and outputs—when they explore the kinetic energy of particles before and after a collision in activities #1-4, and the total kinetic energy of solids in a system in activities #5-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Energy may take different forms (e.g. energy in fields, thermal energy, energy of motion).
Rationale: Students use the idea that the transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a designed or natural system when they investigate kinetic energy transfer via particle collisions in gases, solids, and liquids in activities #1-8.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Unknown practice identifier: 7.7
Rationale: Students investigate how the rate of thermal energy transfer (total kinetic energy at a particle level) depends on how much of a solid is in contact with surrounding material, with regard to the amount of particles that can transfer motion energy (via conduction) to neighboring particles, in activity #7.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: The transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a designed or natural system.
Rationale: Students use models to track how energy transfers from high-energy to low-energy particles through collisions, thus leading to temperature changes in matter.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Energy may take different forms (e.g. energy in fields, thermal energy, energy of motion).
Rationale: Students develop a consensus model in which they explicitly track different kinds of energy, such as the energy from light (energy in fields), the kinetic energy of particles (energy of motion), and thermal energy (energy of an object or substance due to particle motion in the object or substance).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: The transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a designed or natural system.
Rationale: Students’ models account for the transfer of energy into a cup system and how certain features slow this process.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.
Rationale: Students read about different designs for beverage containers that have been effective in minimizing energy transfer. They examine properties of materials or other design features of cups and apply science ideas to make sense of how the structures worked so effectively.

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Elements of Crosscutting Concept(s)
Rationale: Rationale

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: Students predict and explain why design features would minimize energy transfer (effect )in terms of causal mechanisms (particle interactions and light’s interaction with matter).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.
Rationale: Students select at least three design features (structures) for their cup systems. Their choice of design features are ones they believe will minimize energy transfer (function by reducing particle collisions or blocking absorption of light .

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.
Rationale: Students explain the outcomes for different designs and related design features in terms of causal mechanisms (particle interactions and light’s interaction with matter).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.
Rationale: Students select at least three design features (structures) for their cup systems. Their choice of design features are ones they believe will minimize energy transfer by reducing particle collisions or blocking absorption of light (functions).

Elements of Science and Engineering Prac: Patterns in rates of change and other numerical relationships can provide information about natural and human designed systems.
Rationale: Students look for patterns in rates of temperature change across a variety of tests aimed at collecting data on different design features that could minimize energy transfer into a cup system.

Rationale:
